Re ''It's a Word World, or Is It?'' (State of the Art, Sept. 21): WordPerfect's troubles did not begin when Novell bought it. Rather, it shot itself in the foot when it included, around 1994, an incompatible macro engine in Version 6. To upgrade, you had to convert and test your macros. A large portion of its user base agreed with me that the effort outweighed the benefits.

Previously, I had purchased every upgrade. Since then, I haven't sent WordPerfect 10 cents. My macros still work fine, and my decision not to change looks better every year. Corel has done nothing to sell me an upgrade, like providing a 5.1 compatibility mode. Indeed, with contemporary hardware, with enough cache to hold the entire 1 meabyte DOS memeory space, DOS WordPerfect 5.1 works better than ever, even under Windows.

WordPerfect pioneered the concept of the ''clean screen,'' one status line at the bottom and nothing else, no menus, no tool bars, just what you had written. The clutter and distractions of contemporary Windows screens have proved the value of that concept. I may have on my tombstone: ''He never switched from 5.1.''
